explanation:
To decide if any controlling expression in OS_MutSemCreate is an invariant you must inspect the definitions/behaviour of all macros/functions and constants that participate in or can change the values used in conditionals inside this function (and any macros it expands to):

- OS_CHECK_POINTER: a macro invoked at the start; it may expand to an if/return/assert. Its controlling expression must be checked for invariance.
- OS_CHECK_APINAME: same reason as above — it may contain conditional code that could be invariant.
- OS_ObjectIdAllocateNew: the result of this call is stored in return_code and is the subject of the controlling expression if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS). You need its implementation/semantics to know if the returned value can vary at runtime.
- OS_SUCCESS: the constant used in the comparison; its value/definition is required to determine what the comparison means and whether it could be equivalent to a compile-time invariant.
- LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE: passed into OS_ObjectIdAllocateNew; its value can affect the behaviour/return value of that call and therefore affect whether the controlling expression can vary.
- OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET: a macro used to obtain mutex from the object table; it may contain control flow (conditions, assertions) or rely on token semantics — inspect for invariant controlling expressions.
- OS_mutex_table: the object/table symbol used by OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET; its declaration/initializer could make the macro behave in a compile-time-constant way in some builds.
- OS_OBJECT_INIT: a macro that initializes the table entry and may contain conditional statements; its expansion must be checked for invariant control expressions.
- OS_MutSemCreate_Impl: called and its result assigned to return_code; its implementation may contain conditionals (loops/ifs) whose controlling expressions must be examined and may affect subsequent control.
- OS_ObjectIdFinalizeNew: called with the (possibly modified) return_code; its behavior can change the final return_code and may contain control flow that must be checked for invariance.
- OS_printf: commonly used inside check/error macros; included because the check macros (or other called code) may invoke logging conditionally — the macro definitions invoking OS_printf need to be inspected.
- osal_id_t: the type of sem_id; its definition may be required if any macros use compile-time properties of the type (e.g., comparisons against special constants) when expanding checks.
- OS_object_token_t: the type of token; macros like OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET/OS_OBJECT_INIT operate on tokens — their definitions and any associated invariants depend on the token type.
- OS_mutex_internal_record_t: the type of mutex (returned by OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET) — OS_OBJECT_INIT references a member (obj_name) and the macro expansion may include conditionals based on structure fields.

Provide these symbols (their declarations/definitions) to the next analyzer so it can expand macros and inspect the implementations of called functions to determine whether any controlling expression (in the function body or in expanded macros/callees executed directly from this function) is a compile-time invariant in violation of the MISRA rule.
